transcript:
Welcome to Behind the Ticker.
I'm Brad Roth, Chief Investment Officer of Thor Financial Technologies, and portfolio manager
of THLV, the Thor Low Volatility ETF.
Behind the Ticker, uncovers the inner workings of the ETF industry.
We will interview portfolio managers and ETF service providers to dive deep into their
work lives and their businesses.
We will learn the inner workings of their strategies and what drives them as they continue
to grow their company.
Many of these individuals are entrepreneurs, and will have unique and compelling insights
to share as much goes on behind the Ticker.
Please note, nothing in this show is investment advice, and it is meant solely for educational
and entertainment purposes only.
Welcome to Behind the Ticker.
Today we have Paul Weissbrock.
He is from GTS.
They are a market maker for ETFs as well as individuals.
Stocks, they are front and center down on the New York Stock Exchange.
It was nice to talk to Paul today about the ETF industry as a whole.
What they do as market makers as well as what it takes to really make an ETF launch successful
and to go smoothly and to have longevity in this business.
So it is a wonderful conversation with Paul, so please enjoy this episode with Mr. Paul Weissbrock.
Hey Paul, welcome to the show.
Thanks for having me, Brad. I appreciate it.
So can you tell us a little bit about your background and how you have actually made your
way to GTS?
Sure.
I have been involved in the greater ETF ecosystem since the early 2000s.
somewhat by happenstance when I was at Thusquahanna.
At the time I had started there on the Nasdaq OTC market making desk and had an opportunity
to go to the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and work on the specialist posts for spy and DIA
the diamonds and at that point in time this is called at early 2000s.
It was only a handful of ETFs, spreads were rather wide, volumes were certainly relatively low
compared to what we see today and there was just, I don't know that there was a vision that
there would be 3300 ETFs and mutual funds converting to ETFs and the progression that we've seen
over the years and make your asset management firms going into the space.
No one was talking about any of that really.
These were just fairly straightforward market index beta funds that had traders in
interest, you know, the interest of hedge funds and certain, certain managers were using them.
But I think this was well pre ETF model ETF strategist ETF fund of funds.
None of that was really populated and not too many firms were doing it at the time.
So that's for the clock a bit, I then spent some time in an ETF issuer
pacer in 2008, 2009 time frame and obviously they're actually speak for themselves in terms of
believe they have 25 billion in assets at this point in time, a decade later and a broad lineup
of funds. So I saw the merits of being a startup, the challenges of being a startup and the ETF
space on the issuer side. But I have a good awareness of the distribution network and needs
that advisors have and institutions have and what they really look for when screening and adding
ETFs and their investment portfolios. So I joined GTS in 2019, post the acquisition of the market-making
group and lead market-making commitments from Caner Fitzgerald and, you know, proud to be a
member of Reggie's team who has been in this space longer than I would say since the late 90s,
the team here has broad expertise in market-making, both on floor-based trading as well as upstairs
electronic trading and currently we oversee 341 U.S. listed ETFs as lead market-maker,
add another 40 secondary market-maker and we trade across the spectrum well over 3,200 of the
U.S. listed ETFs. So we have, you know, very broad asset class expertise and ability.
So Paul, I always like to ask everybody before we jump into things. What do you like to do when you're
not, you know, what do you like to do outside the office? What are some of hobbies you get you have?
Sure. Hobbies, what one is certainly music? I enjoyed to play and listen to music and it
seems to be easier than ever. You know, is it download albums and create playlists and store
store thousands of songs on something like YouTube music which used to be Google music?
So that's the technology fascinating to me, the ease of use and, you know, the sheer memory of
having something that's just well-advanced compared to say like the iPod that we had
everyone had to just several years ago and five hundred songs was something to to be fascinated about.
Now it's more like you can have a hundred thousand songs full albums than what would have you on your
phone. That's probably number one and number two, I would say basketball, swimming, and swimming
for the most part. Something both things that I ironically picked up, you know, well after high
school in college. So if you talk to or have been introduced to David Shohoff who runs MUSQ,
the music ETF? Yes, sir. We are lead market maker in MUSQ. I should add, we're also lead market maker
in tune to UNE and those are the only two music industry ETFs that I'm aware of, both pretty
new to the landscape. You know, within the last six months, both launched and some of the points I
touched on earlier about YouTube music and the progression of elect, the electrotification,
and if you will, of M23 isn't stuck, it's certainly core to what they're doing in their respective
spots and running those ETFs. I actually saw him recently at the future proof conference in Huntington
Beach just several weeks back. The conference had a music bent on it, obviously. There was
live music on the final day. Yeah, I had, um, I had him on the show actually a few episodes ago. He's
a really interesting guy, cool background. I also saw him down at future proof. I got you and I didn't
run into each other and I was at that concert at the final night. Right. Yeah, likewise. I mean,
the whole music live music aspect at that conference is obviously something unique and I think
David bounced some ideas off of me in terms of, you know, what where the idea for the fun came from,
where the idea for his company came from, but where he sees the future. And it's all all things
that I haven't even considered, which I found fascinating. So let's, let's talk about GTS itself.
Can you explain to me, and to, you know, the advisors or somebody who's going to be coming to
issue an ETF here? What exactly GTS does and, and as simple as a format as you possibly could,
sure. So when an advisor is seeking to launch an ETF, if we, um, taking a account that they've
already selected an exchange New York Stock Exchange as XCO, GTS will provide the initial seed capital,
because to fund a new ETF, you need AP slash market maker seed, that's some service we provide
and as it's placing the first seed order so that the fun reaches the exchanges listing requirements,
it can launch. There are some funds that are self-seated in the sense that they're a mutual
fun conversion, with assets or an SMA and a contract transfer with assets. But that aside, for those
new ETFs that need to launch in a rather conversion, we provide the seed, and then we agreed to
believe market maker on the respective exchange that they choose. And that means that we're acquired
to post reasonable bid offer quotes during all market hours every day of the week. So 930 to
4 o'clock, we have the responsibility to be posting continuous quotes. I, we can't, you know, take
a break and there's, there shouldn't be any gaps in time where we're not quoting or any gaps in
time where we're wide compared to where Nav is. So a barring, you know, system outages or street wide
market data issues, you'll see our quotes bit ask for 340 some odd names right now. And I,
ideally hugging the NAV trying to provide liquidity for orders that come in electronically as well as
from upstairs sources such as, you know, broker dealer desks or custodian desks when they're
transacting an ETF blocks for models for advisors. So what is it about GTS specifically that allows
you guys to win so much business? It seems like you, you know, as a, you know, what we use you guys
as are direct, you know, for for trader now, but what is it about the GTS that you need to
you guys or something that you offer that allows you to get so much of this new issue business?
If I think it's the combination of perfect combination, if you will, of cutting-edge technology
and speed and awareness of future needs on the technological front and that coupled with boots
on the ground experience with different types of clients that are trading or managing said ETFs.
So we, we understand the needs uniquely of a broker dealer block desk that's trading for thousands
of advisors internally for models versus the needs of an RIA ETF strategist who runs an ETF model.
First is say an institution that trades ETFs is just part of their strategy.
Perhaps they're stocking bomb pickers by nature, but when they trade those ETFs because of the
sheer size of the institutional plan, the blocks are large enough that they certainly don't want
to create price impact. So I think that we have fairly broad expertise and that's what just
being in the game for so long. It's speaking with different clients at what their specific needs are
and are oftentimes in the consultative role in terms of examining of portfolios, liquidity,
examining which ETS they currently own or seek to buy and finding if there are anything
in any esoteric details that we should bring to their awareness in terms of product nuances or product
pricing or differences from fund to fund. I think it's a combination of just being in the trading space,
the marketing making space, as well as many of us on this team have ETF wholesaling backgrounds.
And once you can break down the barriers, what the various brokers for and look for
in terms of what makes ETS successful and added to said platform, you can connect the
points of distribution to actionable trading liquidity. And obviously, volume and assets tend to
drive this excessive of ETFs. More so than performance I might add.
Yeah, and I definitely want to talk about that a little bit later. You mentioned their technology
I was just there with you on the floor a couple weeks or last week, I guess it was.
How is technology change? You know, even in the last 10 or 15 years in terms of market
making and trading and kind of where do you see it going even with the advent of AI and will that
have any impact on your business? I think that you'll continually see the need for auto quoting
technology and automated technology, especially with a bevy of dozens of more ETS and different types of
products coming to market. Even though there has been a wave of liquidation, some of the smaller
funds with lower asset bases have closed in 23. I think you'll see the net number after new ETF
launches, which includes mutual fund conversions and SMA and contracts for it is still a positive.
So it's very realistic for me to say, you know, at some point in the next three years,
they're literally likely could be 5,000 ETFs, especially given a lot of the new ETFs will be existing
strategies that have converted from their current form into an ETF. So the longer the short of it is,
it brings a higher level of sophistication of these products and strategies to market
because some of the products that are launching are not their first in class, brand new concepts
if you will to ETF world. You know, Ether products, for example this week, I saw an aluminum strategy
from US commodity funds launching this week as well as the bevy of active managers that
simply have high asset totals in their existing strategy and the fund has the following,
it has a retail investor base that will trade it. All of that needs to be supported by
better technology. Technology that will continue to advance day over day, week over week,
quarter over quarter. I think one example is the, you'd mentioned you alluded to this
than the New York Stock Exchange DMM model, which a fund company can now launch on the New York
Stock Exchange as opposed to the electronic ARCA. And there there are certainly merits to that.
You have a human overlay, if you will, on top of an auto quarter or now a rhythmic based
quarter. And generally there's more market death, fighter spreads, the optics of the fund
tend to be very positive, especially for newcomers that are looking at a new fund. And typically,
you know, the advisors have the same questions that you look at spread, volume, and then the
newness of the fund. Is it a month old or is it a five year morning star record? If the optics
of the fund going into a trade or positive, I eat tight spread in some level of activity,
in some level of market depth, chances of set advisor making a size of allocation or higher.
So I think we can speed that process of launching a fund and again, it's in success points,
50 million, a hundred million a billion in an AUM. These are the conversations about mechanics,
optics, and real-life scenarios, such as buying, you know, 10x, 20x, the average yearly volume
and set product. So I think that the human, the human overlay, if you will, on top of what we're
doing, take the logically in our quoting systems, whether that be on NICI floor or ARCA,
NASDAQ or CBO, because we were active on all of those venues, is certainly important. Understanding
that certain asset classes and certain products are unique from from fund to fund is probably
core to that. And each needs a special level of a tech chain, and a special level of detail
to be successful. So staying on this DMM and floor trader touch and feel, I can attest to all
the positives that has brought us as a firm and in our product. So if you're a, I mean,
really any type of issue or specifically a smaller issue, or I can't recommend making that transition
or launching that way from the start. But the question really is around, you know, two questions here.
One would be, everybody sees the floor traders, you know, can you just kind of give everybody,
what are they doing all day? And what kind of unique skills does a floor trader need in order to do
their job? Sure. On the floor, it is important to recognize that the specialist books consist of
single listed equities that are on the New York Stock Exchange. Many of them well established
S&P 500 companies where there's obviously quite a lot of demand to trade said names on a daily
basis, whether it's index related trading or just sheer shareholder retail interest, something like an
IBM or a Disney or a JP Morgan or a Boeing. Obviously, all these stocks trade are noisy and there
has to be a specialist for a trader maintaining the books. The core of the specialist job is to always
be providing two side of quotes and liquidity and an orderly market, especially in times of news or market
volatility. And it's still required even though the order flow may be going against the specialist
book, they have to provide liquidity. It's not an issue of, you know, it's a specialist losing money
or making money to the trading. Oftentimes, the only real bid in liquidity around is the floor specialist
trying to maintain that orderly market. So, in times of market stress, you know, where there's one
way selling or one way buying for that example, for example, purposes. Specialists is the first stop
in terms of quoting and keeping orders that are coming into the marketplace trading at reasonable
levels. And also matching buyers and sellers weren't necessary. They have a, they have a
acute awareness of which firms may be active and that's certain price limit levels. And in certain
cases may be able to match buyer seller, as well as take down positions for for the sake of stability
liquidity within our own book. So let's pivot to kind of launching an ETF. And from your perspective,
you know, I'd like to take a little look behind the scenes when you're getting ready to take on a new
issue to market, you know, what has to be done before trade day, then what has to be done kind of
on the day of launch? Sure. Before the launch itself, before the first day of trading,
we would highly recommend any clients that the issuers in touch with and their expectation to be
active in the fund in early days of trading. Simply just to check in with their custodians,
whether it be a Schwabber fidelity or an LPL or Raymond James, just to make sure that the ticker
and the new Q-sip is available for trading. Sometimes these things aren't set up until post launch,
simply because it's a function of advisor demand or not. But it certainly pays to make these calls
and figure out the landscape before launch so that there's not a mad scramble or no loss business
for no good reason other than, you know, RIA tried to place order in new ticker, but it was rejected
because it wasn't asked instead of adding to the master database at firm level. That does happen.
That's unfortunate because I feel like the average GTF issue or probably doesn't know what's happening
and sometimes it becomes a sheer function of numbers. There's just dozens of new launch
is 3300 and more to come ETFs and the workload just can't be managed day-to-day without some
human awareness and interaction. So I think one of the most important things to do is just make
sure that your points of distribution where you plan on selling the fund that those gateways are
open and sometimes it's simply just adding a simple and adding a Q-sip to some master database
and having it in there. I think a second point would be simply having a capital market
steam internally if not outsourcing that to a trading sub-advisor is an important role,
it's worthy investment. It leads to successful launches but not just launches themselves but day-to-day
week-week efficiency. So having a team internally or one that you hire and there's obviously several
third parties that are very competent at this. They can watch for anomalous volume in the ETF
if spreads which tend to be pretty consistent ever move away. They can quickly ping the lead market
maker and just ask a quick question or find out if there's a basket anomaly or perhaps some
names in the basket have news or are halted or something like that. At least get to the bottom of
a quickly and figure out why is the spread outside of normal parameters. If that's handled within
seconds as opposed to hours or days by said ETF issuer, you're simply just running a better product.
You're running a more efficient product. You'll have less advisor questions and inquiries
and just a tighter process overall. I think all that just leaves the better sales. It's simply
great leads to a mature result with, we have tight spreads, we have acute awareness of our products,
how they trade minutes a minute, day-to-day and it could become cumbersome to add funds
over time especially if they're different asset classes and they have different trading characteristics.
If you don't have like an internal way of monitoring it all. So growth is obviously a good thing
scale is a good thing. Adding new funds all the time is a good thing. At some point that
day-to-day labor may outstrip your current backbone of support. So we definitely see those that are
successful. Like I said, either investing in their own capital market steam or subbing it out.
But I think the notion of, well, we have, you know, advisor interest in new ETF. So we have assets.
We think these will be successful if we distribute them. That's all great. But I think there has to
be a plan before day one of if any of the above take place. How do we support growth? How do we
support incoming calls? How do we support market maker questions? How do we support anomalous trading?
Do we have a plan? If all of those boxes are checked, I think they're all the fastest
success. Yeah, we've talked about that a lot internally about making sure we're institutionalizing
the business and having all those boxes checked because as we kind of get down the line and I want
to talk about scaling an ETF company. But it's important to have all those boxes checked ahead of
time and so you're not chasing yourself later. You know, when we launched early, you know, we weren't
aware of kind of the issues that can happen in the first 15 and last 15 minutes of trading and
kind of those auction times as well as how certain things can go wrong in those periods and
you know, we had to learn fast and learn quickly and make adjustments. So you're right. I mean,
having all those boxes checked on day one is extremely important. I like the term that you use
their bread. It is institutionalizing, you know, the business because I think that's what it becomes.
In terms of whether it's a firm that's known for one or two neat funds, but they're successful
and they raise assets or are growing line up of, you know, broadly diversified funds to extend
a long short commodity, long short equity may be some dividend value growth type equity ETFs.
Obviously, there's a lot of broad based companies that kind of have something for every season
and for the full tactical or strategic manager. I think the issue is, you know, if we have
dozens of funds, we have hundreds of funds. How do we support internally because on any given day,
something anomalous could happen to one or more of them, largely because, you know, the ETF business,
it's not necessarily easy to track, you know, where volume is coming from, right? You know,
it's kind of a, you know, if it's model based action and you understand that your funds are
being added or subtracted to models, there's some awareness of that in some way to track it,
but even that is done quietly and without footprints in most cases and it's usually
enough to the fact observation. And then the thing comes down to, you know, your shareholders,
which could be its institutions, retail advisors, could be retail investors, self-directed.
They're not necessarily emailing the sponsor, calling the sponsor and saying, hey, tomorrow,
I'm going to allocate $5 million to XYZ, so get ready and, you know, make sure that our orders
are executed correctly. I would say a small percentage actually give the heads up to the ETF
sponsor or the trading firm, market maker, that's involved in the fund. The more that do,
they, they get a great outcome because all eyes and all attention is on to what they wish to do.
But mystery volume, as I call it, it's hard to address when you don't know where it's coming from.
And oftentimes it catches people flat-footed, so we're all, I would say all of the time we're
trying to model better and prepare ourselves better for scenarios where average daily volume
and a certain fund that's usually quite inactive will jump considerably. And they're trying
to track where that's coming from, you know, usually it's model driven.
So we talked a little bit about launches, you know, just from your perspective, what sort of trends
are you seeing in ETF launches that are coming to market? I've seen a lot of kind of niche products,
also a lot of active products. What are you seeing on your side of the desk actually taking
these products to market where things are going? Sure. Yeah, a couple of themes go about it.
Me, some of them may be very obvious, but as the crypto regulation warms up from a regulatory
standpoint to what if you were looking to do, there's a long line of ETF sponsors that are
jumping into the crypto futures and ultimately looking to run spot crypto ETFs. That seems like
an obvious one based on the progression in the last couple weeks and seeing the five lanes as well
as long as it's from firms like Pro Shares and Grayscale and Van Eck at Valkyrie. It's so on.
That's number one. I think number two is continue growth in the buffered to find outcome space.
It took several years for the first billion dollar buffer, but it seems like once that happened,
not only are there more players in that space, but there's hundreds of fountains from various
providers, innovator first trust, payster, true mark, come to mind, in terms of
out audience, all have the fine buffer outcome products, BlackRock has them now too. So there's new
entrance, there's existing players that have been around for five years now in the space and
the assets are exploding. I think why because the retail base of advisors and institutions that
use these have confidence now the products are traded and structured and they they they suit and
need they suit and need within portfolios. So I think you'll continue to see options based or options
overlay ETFs. Whether they're defined outcome buffers or something like AAPI, JP from JP Morgan,
there's no shortage of funds in that space now too. All within the last two or three years.
So it's gone from like a fund category of relative obscurity to something that has billions
and assets and growing as well as new filing. Single stock ETFs long short with leverage continue to
I wouldn't say hit or miss necessarily but there's some that are immediately successful given good
timing and the popularity of the single stock, the media Tesla come from mind and then there's other
stock single stock ETFs which are quite small but the providers I believe think that the the
single stock name will be in play at some point in the future so they want shelf space there.
Again, no shortage of new funds coming to market in that category. Literally,
you know, dozens, dozens if not in the pipeline that have launched already.
So I'm going to ask you a loaded question. It's a simple question but what do
issuers have to do to survive in this business and scale? I like the question first of all
was I think we do a lot of thinking about this. The number one thing that comes to mind
is differentiating between soft historical assets if you will and actual commitments to doing
business in the first 30 days after an ETF launch and that's that's the primary driver. I feel like
if an issue were going to come to market with high confidence they can raise 50 million and 30 days
some of that may be internal via their RIA or other SMA strategies that they manage and convincing
said investors that this new ETF is a better fit for our business and for you let's transition into it.
So that that comfort level needs to be established quickly and it needs to lead to action quickly.
Second of all, everyone has some level of pre-logged marketing which is obviously within compliance
of their new ETF strategy and advisors will either be committed or will wait and see.
If it's wait and see and they want to wait until said ETF has a hundred million assets
as a million shares a day on average daily volume, that becomes a bit of a dice roll for the
issuers in terms of they're waiting for someone else to buy first and it is a chicken in the
Exynario which could lead to managing a fund with low assets month over month quarter or over quarter
waiting for others to appear and buy it and you have you know basically a bunch of retail
advisors that are waiting for activity to happen outside of them before they are comfortable.
So I think yeah that's my answer would be establishing a level of confidence on how quickly you
can get the 50 million because it's important to get to that scale and pay fixed costs that are
you know they're essential to running the fund officially and once you get to those levels
50 million and a hundred million you can then call the retail platforms more confidence and
a higher success rate and get them to agree to allow the ETF to be distributed on said platform
and there's no shortage of model driven and ETF driven advisors out there sometimes becomes an issue
there's 3000 plus ETFs and they have limited bandwidth so they need some help from a home office level
the screen if you will or filter what they can buy and what they can so getting to the you know
getting to the point of success is quickly getting on to those platforms not three to five years
for now but ideally inside of a year. Right yeah no I I couldn't agree more and I guess just
one one more last question with regards to this is like okay let's say you you do all those things right
you you have a successful launch you get to 50 a hundred million you have you know some pretty good
solid committed clients so you're covering your overhead. Is it just is it time and patience and
marketing and waiting for the right environment in order to maybe hit that home run or really

to kind of push the fund as time goes on. Yeah I like all the points that you mentioned in terms
of being essential I would recommend all those and I would add to it if if one of the the points
that you made just simply doesn't line up with the current market I eat perhaps it's just a
thematic strategy that's performing poorly in the short term you know it's tough to sell something
that has bad relative owner performance at that moment in time. I think instead of while we're
just going to wait until performance turns around or we're going to wait and see what happens and just
you know the phones are quiet until then that's not a great strategy because it's the you know it's
waiting and hoping and the clock is running because obviously there are fixed fixed expenses
involved that running in ETF. I think the the better strategy in that scenario where you're simply
just selling until being as out of favor hasn't been embraced yet and that's a common problem
especially with all the new ETFs out there is to just look at what your best peers or competitors

important to just look at who you think your closest peers are and there may not be an Apple
Apple's comparison in many cases but that is probably the best source of intel because eventually
